in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were live over zoom and office hours were also offered over zoom.
combination of recorded lectures and live lectures.
none
n/a
Lectures were also recorded
The lectures were held live on zoom but we could also watch the recordings later.
Students recorded short presentations on their final projects and we watch each others'. I thought this was really fun.
Piazza and office hours
Class were also recorded.
Lectures were live virtual, but I always watched them recorded after the fact.
Piazza
None
None.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a great intro into various algorithms to create agents to play simple games. The course does a good job of teaching the theory behind the algorithms as well as giving the students the opportunity to implement the algorithms in PSETs.
Various games (combinatorial, simultaneous games), concepts use to develop and solve games, search trees, basic machine learning concepts.
all about different types of games and how to write programs to find optimal strategies
I learned about computational techniqies for developing strategies for a vareity of games
Interesting crash course in developing AI agents to solve different games. Learned a lot about how to actually implement and use algorithms you might have learned in past courses like AI etc.
I learned about various algorithms for playing games optimally such as backtracking, monte carlo tree search, and q-learning.
How to develop intelligent agents for different types of games, and explaining the basic mathematical principles behind these agents.
Lots of knowledge of general algorithms and their applications to games.

I learned about different techniques for creating game-playing agents. I also learned which games can be solved completely and which cannot along with the techniques that work best for certain types of games. A lot of the techniques for game-playing are more widely applicable as well, and it was particularly interesting to learn about reinforcement learning and neural networks.

I learned a lot about the different kinds of games and the different approaches to working with them. I didn't really know anything about game complexity or the different categories of games before this class, so I learned a lot throughout the semester.

The class went over game AI techniques, algorithms, and approaches from the beginnings of the field to the present day (tree searches to neural nets) and I learned a great many ways to apply these techniques to a plethora of challenges in games. It was nice to apply what I learned in game theory in a computational intelligence context-- having that experience definitely makes things somewhat more interesting.
I learned Python, how to be good at games, some cool algorithms, and how machine learning works. A nice mix of concepts in a fun setting.
Mostly learned about algorithms for playing various kinds of games. Also learned a little bit about properties of good games and generation of games.
Programming agents to win or competitively play games; game theory; applications of learning algorithms and artificial intelligence.
I leaned about machine learning through games.

I learned how to classify games in order to employ one of a variety of strategies in approaching/solving different games. Strategies included brute-force solving the state space/tree search, minimax + alpha/beta pruning, Monte Carlo Tree Search, and Q-learning.
Knowledge of application of ML in games

Learned a lot of interesting algorithms to solve various board games and other types of games. Strengthened overall coding skills through really interesting and fun assignments that always applied algorithms we learned to various games.
I learned about deep learning/computational intelligence algorithms such as backtracking, dynamic programming, minimax, monte carlo, q-learning and more for games.
Applying a variety of techniques to creating agents that play games
Algorithms for creating intelligent game agents.
Practice using specific algorithms used in game solving agents.
Backtracking, game tree search techniques, learning algorithms, saddle points for simultaneous games, dynamic programming

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is extremely well taught and there is a clear plan and progression throughout the semester. Each topic seems to build on the previous topic so that nothing feels overwhelming. There were no major issue in this course that need addressing in my opinion.
Various concepts, assignments cover a lot of important topics learned in class
LOVED THIS CLASS super engaging, great PSETS, perfect for 2x speed watching and very fun content
Veyr enjoyable, no complaints

Strengths: interesting course material, interesting and clear assignments 
Weaknesses: lectures could be a bit dry and boring. Best lectures were when students got to participate/play a sample version of a game with Prof Glenn!

Strengths: The problem sets were constructed well and were challenging without being overwhelmingly difficult. Whenever I did get stuck I was able to go to office hours and the ULAs were very helpful. It was also very nice to have 5 late days we could use whenever we wanted. Having the lectures recorded was also great because I could watch them multiple times and replay the specific portions that were most relevant. I also liked having 3 quizzes instead of more stressful larger tests.

Weaknesses: I liked the final project but I wish the guidelines had been a bit clearer from the beginning, especially regarding test cases and how much of a writeup we needed. There was a stressful period around October where there was either a quiz or pset due every week for about 5 weeks. I would add at least one week off in the middle so that students can regroup in case they have started to fall behind.

Strengths: Psets were fair and help me learn the material, notes helped with the psets
Weaknesses: The OneNote notes that Glenn likes to use are not that useful unless you watch the lecture where he writes out the notes. There are no psets based on the last few topics, so I did not diligently study them

Strengths - some fun psets, professor Glenn really tried engaging with everyone in the class, the final project was a great way to explore something we were interested in 
Weaknesses - hard to understand some of the expectations for psets, some psets were not really based on understanding of code, I do not know how you would be able to do psets in a normal semester as you need to copy down exactly what was said in lecture to do them
Lectures could be made more exciting, but this is my only complaint. Everything else about this course was great, lectures matched well with psets and there was plenty of support available to us.

Strengths: Fun psets, interesting content if you like games, probably Glenn's best taught course
Weaknesses: Some psets (*cough* Q-learning *cough*) involve hours and hours of guess-and-check fine-tuning certain parameters to achieve good performance. This got incredibly tedious, and there was no real learning involved there.

The class was really good in that it gave the background knowledge you needed during the class. There were people in the class who had clearly studied games before, but we still learned all of the basic theory and background, which was helpful for those of us who had never learned about games.

I thought the topic was really fun and the projects very satisfying to do. Professor Glenn is really knowledgeable and nice. I like the mix of approaches and techniques learned, and I was surprised at how simple machine learning is now that I've gotten to use it. Having an open final project was also really cool, I haven't had that in many of my classes before.

The lectures were great! Professor Glenn isn't the most exciting lecturer you will meet (and this was also a Zoom semester), but he made the lectures interesting by varying the kind of content (i.e. including live gameplay, videos, graphics, etc. instead of just slides). The course managed to cover a lot in the semester, and also talked about the latest research which I really appreciated.

One weakness was the final project process. We had to leave feedback on video presentations made by others, but we never actually got to view any of the feedback left on our presentations. As a result, the process wasn't very useful. It would have been better if the videos were real proposals that we could then adapt in response to feedback.

Extremely engaging class with class participation opportunities and examples given my professor on how to play games that we programmed. Class was a great balance of computational intelligence and gameplay.
Very interesting course, however, the lectures were sometimes a little boring. The content was very interesting, but if lecture was just a little more engaging the class would be perfect.

This is a very enjoyable and laid back CS elective. The problem sets are super fun to do, grading on problem sets and quizzes is very fair, and Professor Glenn is great as always. No weaknesses to report.
I loved all the programming assignments. They were not only very fair in terms of difficulty but also really fun to do. Most fun class Ive taken at Yale by a long shot.

The problem sets are pretty interesting and fun, however, some of the assignments suffer from being reduced to changing parameters the entire time. Lectures covered exciting material, but it was hard to pay attention to Glenn without being distracted at home. Grading remains an issue in this class too.

Really cool topics, reasonable deadlines for psets

Think the final project could have benefited from more structure/an actual spec on requirementsneeded to piece everything together from lectures + piazza posts
All good

Strengths: Clear on what assignments are looking for. 
Weaknesses: office hours structure

Strengths: I thought Professor Glenn taught this course really well. He explains the core concepts clearly and provides good indicators of how to tackle the problem sets effectively. Although I ended up watching lectures asynchronously, Professor Glenn structures the lectures well, and it feels like they all build on one another (for the most part).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online lectures functioned as well as an in person lecture would have. The PSETs were also no different. The evaluations (3 short quizzes) were slightly different than usual but still provided a good opportunity to review the material. Overall, I think this course was well adapted to online.
Recorded lectures, prof provides lecture notes
loved the iPad notes, loved the recorded lectures, office hours were alright I just think they are better in person
as good as it could be

Lectures could be a lot more engaging. Because it was hard for me to stay engaged during the live lectures, I usually watched the recorded version of the lectures. However, it's really easy to fall behind and just not watch the lecture. What worked in other classes was having a small, 5 point graded lecture quiz due a few days after the lecture was available. This actually forced me to watch the lecture soon after it was recorded and kept me from falling behind.
This class was likely even better online. Being able to rewatch lectures greatly enhanced my learning, and the online quizzes were effective.
Succeeded: The Canvas quizzes that replaced the in-person quizzes were easy to access and take.

I wish there were more quizzes/knowledge checks. Additionally, it would have been nice to have a textbook or other reference material. Piazza was a great tool in this course, and I really liked how office hours were a general meeting so that conceptual questions could be asked by everyone
The Zoom lectures were about the same as they would have been live, so the course seems well-adapted for pandemic times.

I thought of all my classes, this had the best Zoom chat! Students would occasionally make jokes, and Professor Glenn would always laugh and also answer any questions that appeared. The virtual environment may have even enhanced certain things, like the ability for some of Professor Glenn's notes to already be "on the board" and playing games live without having to deal with a projector. Overall, I think this course did very well online.
Professor gave us a whole new list of dates and tests half way through the semester, and was quite rude about it when asked about it on Piazza

Professor Glenn did a great job of gearing this course towards learning during the pandemic. He always posted lecture recording and his notes very shortly after the live lecture. His notes are fantastic and are color-coded extremely well to facilitate learning. He was very responsive and helpful on Piazza.
Recorded lectures are easily the best thing for CS classes.
Async lectures were solid, psets were straightforward
The office hours were good.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This is an incredible course that lets you apply CS knowledge to an interesting and fun field.

Yes, you get to learn about many types of games (combinatorial, simultaneous), and practice coding search trees. You also get to come up with your own algorithm for a game of your choice for final project.

I had strong feelings about Glenn's lack of clarity but I would strongly recommend this class! You can tell Glenn really enjoys teaching this material and I learned a lot from it. Even if you aren't super interested in games, I would say you learn a lot (and maybe it will make you better at it/ more interested).
YES! Absolutely loved this class, everyone told me Glenn was slow, but then content was really interesting and I was never bored
ANyone who is interested in AI or game playing in general (a CS student obviously) will thoroughly enjoy this course

I would definitely recommend this class! Glenn's notes are really great and he is one of the most fun professors in the CS department. The psets were fairly interesting and unique applications of algorithms you may have learned in other classes. A great CS elective!!!
Yes! It was interesting AND a gut!

Yes. This is a very solid CS elective, especially if you are interested in AI or Games. You can also do all the assignments in Python, so you can get a lot of practice with a useful language. I really think this is one of the better CS electives because you learn a lot of new concepts without it being horribly difficult.
To those interested in game theory, general board games or puzzles, or AI, a definite yes. For me, I was only interested in AI, but it was still an eye-opening course where I learned a lot.

Yes, if you are interested in learning about the logic and algorithms behind some popular games. However, it is definitely more math focused than other CS courses and requires a lot more exact understanding of topics in order to do psets which is not everyone's cup of tea

Absolutely!! This was one of my favorite classes I've taken so far. The content is not only applicable outside of the course, but it's also so much fun and touches on several fields. Psets are not too long or difficult, and they're in Python which is great. Taking 223 may be helpful for this class (but is not necessary).

I would recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in the theory behind games (two player, one player, board games, video games, ...) and how to create good game-playing agents. The content focuses on game-playing but the techniques are more generally applicable, which is nice. If you like Glenn's teaching, I would say this is probably his best-taught course.
Sure! This is a fun class. The content is interesting and the problem sets are not too difficult. Overall a nice, relaxed course to add to your schedule.
I think this was a really interesting course and I would definitely recommend it to another student. The problem sets were interesting and fun to work on.

Yes-- you gain an appreciation and understanding of game intelligence as it developed, and it gives you the tools to understand modern approaches to AI in games. Note that the majority of the class is concerned with perfect-information board or card games and not necessarily modern video games, although the class does touch on that.

Yes. It is a nice introduction to a lot of cool algorithms and machine learning. Professor Glenn really knows what he's talking about, and he's friendly and fun. Being able to choose the language you do most assignments in is nice, I used it as an excuse to learn C++ and Python.

I think the psets can be tricky. As opposed to some other CS classes, where psets can be a slow build, I felt these psets made no sense to me for a period of time, clicked, then were finished in a very short time. It depends how quickly things click for you.

Yes! If you are interested in games, or even just in AI, this is a very interesting class. It is taught well and the problem sets are enjoyable and not too hard. I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the subject, and it is a great CS elective if you need one.
Yes- the best cs elective Ive taken
Yes. This is a great course if you want to get started in machine learning or if you are just interested in games.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone looking for an easy CS elective, a fun CS course, or to learn a bit about games. There's a good amount of overlap with material covered in AI (CPSC 470), especially through the first half of the class with DFS, minimax + alpha/beta pruning, but it's still very interesting content. The class is easy -- problem sets are very doable, and if you've taken a bunch of CS courses they'll never really take you more than 5-10 hours (every other week). There are no exams, just a couple of very straightforward quizzes sprinkled throughout the semester. Professor Glenn was great as always and his passion for games makes the course very enjoyable. I would definitely recommend.
Yes. By far the best CS course Ive taken here. Maybe the best course overall as well.
Yes, I would if the student is interested in how computer science algorithms apply to games.

Very cool course where you can learn a bunch of new algorithms and techniques. Definitely recommend to juniors and up (helps to have Python experience, not a lot of hand holding if you can't design and implement a program by yourself).
Yes, it's an interesting class.
If they are particularly interested in solving games.

Yes absolutely--especially if you haven't taken an AI class yet. This class touches on a lot of relevant AI topics like minimax, alpha-beta, etc., but even if you have taken AI, this class is still useful, since you spend time coding things like MCTS and Q-learning in Python. All in all, a great CS elective to take, with a reasonable workload.
